Article.Abstract: The objective of the study was to identify Mycobacterium leprae-specific immunogenic peptides for the development of a skin test reagent. Such a reagent is required for the detection of M. leprae infection and possibly for the diagnosis of patients with active leprosy. For this purpose, we analyzed the in vitro responses of human peripheral blood mononuclear cell (PBMCs) to peptides from the 35 kDa protein of M. leprae. This protein is of interest since it has no homologue within the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex, although it has a homologue in Mycobacterium avium. The subjects enrolled in the study were paucibacillary (PB) and multibacillary (MB) leprosy patients, healthy contacts, and non-contacts. Seventy-three PB and 124 MB leprosy patients were recruited from four leprosy clinics in Thailand. Fifty-seven healthy contacts were household contacts. Twenty non-leprosy contacts had no family history of or exposure to leprosy. PBMCs from individuals were tested for stimulation with 12 overlapping peptides from the M. leprae 35 kDa protein using the lymphocyte proliferation assay. These peptides were located in four areas containing three to six residues which were distinct for the M. leprae product in comparison to that from M. avium. Four peptides (p60-76, p132-151, p206-224 and p267-286), which were the most permissive from each region and recognized by non-contacts with significantly lower frequencies than other subject groups, were identified. From this preliminary result, we conclude that these four peptides were likely to be M. leprae-specific.
Article.ArticleTitle: T-cell recognition of peptides from the Mycobacterium leprae 35 kDa protein in Thai leprosy patients, healthy contacts, and non-contacts.
Article.Affiliations: Sasakawa Research Building, Raj-Pracha-Samasai Institute, Leprosy Division, Department of Communicable Disease Control, Ministry of Public Health, Nonthaburi, 11000, Thailand. booschua@health.moph.go.th.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Adult; Bacterial Proteins(chemistry; immunology); Epitopes; Female; Genes, MHC Class II; HLA-DR Antigens(genetics; immunology); Humans; Leprosy(diagnosis; immunology); Lymphocyte Activation; Male; Molecular Sequence Data; Molecular Weight; Mycobacterium avium(immunology); Mycobacterium leprae(immunology); Peptides(chemical synthesis; chemistry; immunology); Species Specificity; Thailand

Epitope.EpitopeComments: 5 mismatches with M. Avium homolog region: R61, V64, T72, A74 & L76. Named 35KDa protein in the manuscript. It is the only antigenic protein in M. leprae with no homolog in M. Tuberculosis. It has an homolog in M. avium.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy non-contact group was used for analyzing the specificity of the response seen in the infected individuals.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Subjects with SI (cpm with antigen / cpm without antigen)>2.5 were considered responders.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Treated and untreated leprosy patients and households contacts are considered infected.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Subjects with SI (cpm with antigen / cpm without antigen)>2.5 were considered responders. The figure is the sum of responders from PB and MB leprosy patients and healthy household contacts. Non-contact group had no responders, suggesting that this epitope is probably specific for M. leprae.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: 6 mismatches with M. Avium homolog region: C133, V136, F141, V147, P149, E150. Named 35KDa protein in the manuscript. It is the only antigenic protein in M. leprae with no homolog in M. Tuberculosis. It has an homolog in M. avium.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Treated and untreated leprosy patients and households contacts are considered infected.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Subjects with SI (cpm with antigen / cpm without antigen)>2.5 were considered responders. The figure is the sum of responders from PB and MB leprosy patients and healthy household contacts. Non-contact group had no responders, suggesting that this epitope is probably specific for M. leprae.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Subjects with SI (cpm with antigen / cpm without antigen)>2.5 were considered responders.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy non-contact group was used for analyzing the specificity of the response seen in the infected individuals.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: After a 7 day incubation with the peptide, PBMC did not proliferate.

The figure is the sum of responders from PB and MB leprosy patients and healthy household contacts. Non-contact group had no responders, suggesting that this epitope is probably specific for M. leprae.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: 6 mismatches with M. Avium homolog region: T268, A271, S272, D273, R274, V285. Named 35KDa protein in the manuscript. It is the only antigenic protein in M. leprae with no homolog in M. Tuberculosis. It has an homolog in M. avium.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy non-contact group was used for analyzing the specificity of the response seen in the infected individuals.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Subjects with SI (cpm with antigen / cpm without antigen)>2.5 were considered responders. This % of responders is significantly different from infected groups.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Treated and untreated leprosy patients and households contacts are considered infected.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Subjects with SI (cpm with antigen / cpm without antigen)>2.5 were considered responders. The figure is the sum of responders from PB and MB leprosy patients and healthy household contacts. Non-contact group had 1 out of 20 responders, giving a significant difference that suggests this epitope is probably specific for M. leprae.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: 7 mismatches with M. Avium homolog region: R61, V64, T72, A74, L76, E78 & F80. Named 35KDa protein in the manuscript. It is the only antigenic protein in M. leprae with no homolog in M. Tuberculosis. It has an homolog in M. avium.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Treated and untreated leprosy patients and households contacts are considered infected.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Subjects with SI (cpm with antigen / cpm without antigen)>2.5 were considered responders. The figure is the sum of responders from PB and MB leprosy patients and healthy household contacts. Because there were a 10% responders in the non-contact group and there were no differences in reactivity against this peptide between ill and healthy contacts, it was not considered a candidate M. leprae epitope.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy non-contact group was used for analyzing the specificity of the response seen in the infected individuals.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Subjects with SI (cpm with antigen / cpm without antigen)>2.5 were considered responders. 10% of the non-contact group responded, giving no statistically significant differences between the groups and implying that the epitope is probably not specific to M. leprae.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: 5 mismatches with M. Avium homolog region: T72, A74, L76, E78 & F80. Named 35KDa protein in the manuscript. It is the only antigenic protein in M. leprae with no homolog in M. Tuberculosis. It has an homolog in M. avium.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Subjects with SI (cpm with antigen / cpm without antigen)>2.5 were considered responders. The figure is the sum of responders from PB and MB leprosy patients and healthy household contacts. There were no responders in the non-contact group, but since the general reactivity was lower than with the other peptides, it was not considered a candidate M. leprae epitope.
